title: How to Find Standard Deviation on the TI–84

steps.title: Press the STAT button on your calculator.
steps.content: Press the STAT button on your calculator. It's in the third column of keys. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Select the Edit menu and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Select the Edit menu and press ↵ Enter . It's the first option on the menu. You will see columns (lists) labeled L1 through L6. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Clear existing data from the lists.
steps.content: Clear existing data from the lists. If there's already data in any of the columns, use these steps to remove it before you continue: [3] X Research source Use the arrow keys to navigate to L1 (the first column). Press ⎚ Clear . Press ↵ Enter . Repeat for other lists with data.

steps.title: Enter your data set into the L1 column.
steps.content: Enter your data set into the L1 column. Press the ↵ Enter key after each value.

steps.title: Press the STAT button to return to the menu.
steps.content: Press the STAT button to return to the menu.

steps.title: Press the right-arrow to switch to the CALC tab.
steps.content: Press the right-arrow to switch to the CALC tab. It's the second menu tab at the top of the screen. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Press the 2ND button and then 1 to select L1.
steps.content: Press the 2ND button and then 1 to select L1. You'll only need to do this if you have a T1-84 Plus model and don't already see "L1" next to "List." [5] X Research source Some non-plus models may skip this screen and display your results automatically.

steps.title: Select Calculate and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Select Calculate and press ↵ Enter . The TI-84 will now display standard deviation calculations for the set of values. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Find the standard deviation value next to Sx or σx.
steps.content: Find the standard deviation value next to Sx or σx . These should be the 4th and 5th results in the list. You may have to scroll down to view both values. [7] X Research source Sx shows the standard deviation for a sample, while σx shows the standard deviation for a population. The value you'll use depends on whether you used data from a sample or a full population. [8] X Research source A lower standard deviation value means that the values in your list don't vary much from the mean, while a higher value means your data is more spread out. [9] X Research source x̄ represents the mean, or average, of the values. Σx represents the sum of all values.
